title: The Aftermath of a YouTube Apology
description: Quantifying the lasting impact of a YouTube controversy.

slides.text: vlogpology (noun): when a famous YouTuber becomes embroiled in a controversy, makes headlines, and releases an apology video.
There have been plenty of articles dissecting this phenomenon, but maybe you glossed over them for a while like we did.
But when YouTuber apology videos became Halloween costumes, we knew it was time to investigate.
slides.nerd: YouTube video of the DIY Halloween costume.

slides.text: But why YouTubers?
All sorts of celebrities have controversies that end with public apologies. But few have to shit where they eat — so to speak — like YouTubers. Plus, thereâ€™s data ðŸ¤“.
We researched nearly every possible popular YouTuber with a documented controversy in the past few years and found <mark>34</mark> with apology videos.
slides.nerd: We analyzed 20,000 accounts and cross-referenced with Wikipedia, X, and Y to look for channels with controversy or apology details. We then manually vetted the results for false positives and reduced to channels with at least 90 days of subscriber data on both sides of the apology.

slides.text: The most common controversy type was insensitive videos, like the notorious <mark>Logan Paul</mark> video.
This was closely followed by vloggers like <mark>Laura Lee</mark> apologizing for racist comments theyâ€™ve made.
Some didnâ€™t fit neatly into a box, as was the case with <mark>Jenna Marbles.</mark>
Here is everyone. We noticed that <mark>beauty YouTubers</mark> have a curiously large share of the shame pie.
Beauty vloggers dominated the headlines, so weâ€™ll focus on these noteworthy <mark>nine YouTubers</mark> to breakdown what we found.
<mark>Step One</mark> To measure impact we can look at how their channel subscriptions (subs) grew, starting with their pre-controversy trajectory. Where were they headed?
We compare their daily total subs to their pre-controversy max. As expected, nearly all channels were gaining subs.
Steeper lines means faster growth. <mark class=non>Jake Paul</mark> (not a beauty vlogger) more than doubled his subs in the three months prior to his controversy.
<mark>Step Two</mark> What was the effect on their subs rate after they released their apology?
We go from relatively consistent growth to a range of reactions post-apology.
<mark>Step Three</mark> To better understand the trends, we classified their growth as: fast, moderate, stable, or negative.
The shift was <mark class=pos>positive</mark> for some. For others it was <mark class=neg>negative</mark>.
<mark class=pos>Gabriel Zamora</mark> received a big boost by getting wrapped up in a feud with YouTube royalty Jeffree Star.
Whereas <mark class=neg>Laura Leeâ€™s</mark> questionable apology video (since removed) didnâ€™t exactly help her audience development...
